sub_topic: Finding eigenvalues and eigenvectors of a matrix using power iteration method
message_1: Consider a $3 \times 3$ matrix given by $A=\begin{bmatrix}-2&1&1\\1&-2&1\\1&1&-2\end{bmatrix}$. Use the power iteration method to find the largest eigenvalue $\lambda_1$ of $A$, along with its corresponding eigenvector $\textbf{v}_1$. Take the initial approximation vector to be $\textbf{x}_0=\begin{bmatrix}1\\1\\1\end{bmatrix}$. Perform 5 iterations of the power iteration method and round your final answer to three decimal places.
message_2:
To perform the power iteration method, we will repeatedly multiply the matrix $A$ by the approximation vector $\textbf{x}_k$ and normalize the result to obtain the next approximation vector $\textbf{x}_{k+1}$. After 5 iterations, we will estimate the largest eigenvalue $\lambda_1$ and its corresponding eigenvector $\textbf{v}_1$.

Iteration 1:
$\textbf{x}_1 = A\textbf{x}_0 = \begin{bmatrix}-2&1&1\\1&-2&1\\1&1&-2\end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix}1\\1\\1\end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix}0\\0\\0\end{bmatrix}$

Since the result is a zero vector, we cannot normalize it. We need to slightly modify the initial approximation vector to avoid this issue. Let's use $\textbf{x}_0=\begin{bmatrix}1\\1\\1.01\end{bmatrix}$ instead.

Iteration 1 (modified):
$\textbf{x}_1 = A\textbf{x}_0 = \begin{bmatrix}-2&1&1\\1&-2&1\\1&1&-2\end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix}1\\1\\1.01\end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix}0\\0\\0.01\end{bmatrix}$

Normalize $\textbf{x}_1$:
$\textbf{x}_1 = \frac{\textbf{x}_1}{\|\textbf{x}_1\|} = \begin{bmatrix}0\\0\\1\end{bmatrix}$

Iteration 2:
$\textbf{x}_2 = A\textbf{x}_1 = \begin{bmatrix}-2&1&1\\1&-2&1\\1&1&-2\end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix}0\\0\\1\end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix}1\\1\\-1\end{bmatrix}$

Normalize $\textbf{x}_2$:
$\textbf{x}_2 = \frac{\textbf{x}_2}{\|\textbf{x}_2\|} = \frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}\begin{bmatrix}1\\1\\-1\end{bmatrix} \approx \begin{bmatrix}0.577\\0.577\\-0.577\end{bmatrix}$

Iteration 3:
$\textbf{x}_3 = A\textbf{x}_2 \approx \begin{bmatrix}-2&1&1\\1&-2&1\\1&1&-2\end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix}0.577\\0.577\\-0.577\end{bmatrix} \approx \begin{bmatrix}-0.577\\-0.577\\0.577\end{bmatrix}$

Normalize $\textbf{x}_3$:
$\textbf{x}_3 = \frac{\textbf{x}_3}{\|\textbf{x}_3\|} \approx \begin{bmatrix}-1\\-1\\1\end{bmatrix}$

Iteration 4:
$\textbf{x}_4 = A\textbf{x}_3 \approx \begin{bmatrix}-2&1&1\\1&-2&1\\1&1&-2\end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix}-1\\-1\\1\end{bmatrix} \approx \begin{bmatrix}0\\0\\2\end{bmatrix}$

Normalize $\textbf{x}_4$:
$\textbf{x}_4 = \frac{\textbf{x}_4}{\|\textbf{x}_4\|} \approx \begin{bmatrix}0\\0\\1\end{bmatrix}$

Iteration 5:
$\textbf{x}_5 = A\textbf{x}_4 \approx \begin{bmatrix}-2&1&1\\1&-2&1\\1&1&-2\end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix}0\\0\\1\end{bmatrix} \approx \begin{bmatrix}1\\1\\-1\end{bmatrix}$

Normalize $\textbf{x}_5$:
$\textbf{x}_5 = \frac{\textbf{x}_5}{\|\textbf{x}_5\|} \approx \frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}\begin{bmatrix}1\\1\\-1\end{bmatrix} \approx \begin{bmatrix}0.577\\0.577\\-0.577\end{bmatrix}$

Now, we can estimate the largest eigenvalue $\lambda_1$ using the Rayleigh quotient:
$\lambda_1 \approx \frac{\textbf{x}_5^T A \textbf{x}_5}{\textbf{x}_5^T \textbf{x}_5} \approx \frac{\begin{bmatrix}0.577&0.577&-0.577\end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix}-2&1&1\\1&-2&1\\1&1&-2\end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix}0.577\\0.577\\-0.577\end{bmatrix}}{\begin{bmatrix}0.577&0.577&-0.577\end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix}0.577\\0.577\\-0.577\end{bmatrix}} \approx -3$

So, the largest eigenvalue $\lambda_1 \approx -3$, and its corresponding eigenvector $\textbf{v}_1 \approx \begin{bmatrix}0.577\\0.577\\-0.577\end{bmatrix}$.
